cold-process.name: Cold process
cold-process.summary: The most popular method for handmade soap. Oils and lye react at low temperatures, preserving beneficial compounds.
cold-process.description:
Cold process (CP) soapmaking combines oils with lye solution at relatively low temperatures (typically 38-54°C). The saponification reaction generates its own heat but doesn't require external heating.

This method preserves heat-sensitive compounds in oils and allows for creative designs like swirls and layers. The trade-off is a required 4-6 week cure time before use.

steps.title: Prepare workspace and equipment
steps.description: Set up all equipment and measure out ingredients before starting. Ensure good ventilation and put on safety gear (goggles and gloves).
tips: Line moulds with freezer paper if needed
Have vinegar nearby to neutralize lye spills
Clear workspace of clutter
warnings: Always wear safety goggles and gloves when handling lye

steps.title: Measure oils and fats
steps.description: Weigh solid fats and liquid oils separately into your soap pot. Melt solid fats over low heat, then add liquid oils and allow to cool to target temperature.
tips: Weigh directly into container using tare function
Melt solid fats first, then add liquid oils
Target oil temperature: 38-54°C

steps.title: Prepare lye solution
steps.description: Weigh water into a heat-resistant container. Weigh lye separately. Slowly add lye to water (never water to lye), stirring until fully dissolved.
tips: Always add lye to water, not water to lye
Stir until all crystals dissolve
Solution will heat to 93°C+; let cool
warnings: Lye solution releases caustic fumes; work in ventilation

steps.title: Combine oils and lye
steps.description: When both mixtures are within 5°C of each other and at target temperature, slowly pour lye solution into oils while stirring.
tips: Pour in a thin stream while stirring
Temperatures between 38-54°C work well
Exact temperature match less critical than often stated

steps.title: Blend to trace
steps.description: Alternate stick blending (2-3 second bursts) with hand stirring until mixture reaches trace. At trace, a drizzle of batter leaves a visible trail on the surface.
tips: Keep blender submerged to avoid air bubbles
Light trace: thin pudding, best for swirls
Medium trace: thick pudding, good for most designs
warnings: Don't over-blend; trace can accelerate quickly

steps.title: Add extras at trace
steps.description: Stir in essential oils, colourants, and other additives at light to medium trace. Work quickly if recipe accelerates trace.
tips: Pre-disperse colourants in oil to prevent speckling
Add fragrance last to preserve scent
Reserve some batter before colouring for swirl designs

steps.title: Pour into mould
steps.description: Pour soap batter into prepared mould. Tap mould gently to release air bubbles. Create textured top or smooth with spatula.
tips: Pour from low height to minimize air bubbles
Work quickly with fast-moving recipes
Tap mould firmly on counter to settle batter

steps.title: Insulate or refrigerate
steps.description: For gel phase: cover and insulate mould with towels. For non-gel: leave uncovered or refrigerate. Gel produces brighter colours and faster unmoulding.
tips: Gel phase: wrap in towels, leave 24 hours
Non-gel: refrigerate for 24 hours
Partial gel creates darker ring in center

steps.title: Unmould and cut
steps.description: After 24-48 hours, soap should be firm enough to unmould. Cut loaves into bars with soap cutter or knife.
tips: Soap should be firm but give slightly when pressed
High-olive recipes may need 48-72 hours
Cut within a few days before soap hardens

steps.title: Cure
steps.description: Place bars on curing rack with space between each. Cure for 4-6 weeks in a cool, dry area with good airflow.
tips: Turn bars weekly for even curing
Cure longer for harder, milder bars
High-olive castile benefits from 6-12 month cure

disadvantages: Must work with caustic raw soap

references.note: Cold saponification process and cure time research

hot-process.name: Hot process
hot-process.summary: Soap is cooked until saponification completes. Ready to use sooner than cold process but with a rustic appearance.
hot-process.description:
Hot process (HP) soapmaking uses external heat to accelerate and complete saponification during the cooking phase. This produces soap that's safe to use within days rather than weeks, though curing still improves the bar.

The trade-off is a more rustic, textured appearance and less opportunity for intricate designs. Hot process is excellent for salvaging batches that separated or accelerated too quickly.

steps.title: Prepare workspace and equipment
steps.description: Set up slow cooker or double boiler. Prepare all ingredients and safety equipment as for cold process.
tips: Slow cooker on low works well
Have spatula ready for stirring
Ensure mould is ready before cooking completes
warnings: Same safety precautions as cold process
Hot soap can splatter during cook

steps.title: Combine oils and lye
steps.description: Follow cold process steps to combine oils and lye solution. Bring to light trace with stick blender.
tips: Temperature less critical than cold process
Light trace is sufficient before cooking

steps.title: Cook the soap
steps.description: Cover and cook on low heat. Soap will go through stages: separation, applesauce, mashed potato, vaseline. Stir every 15-20 minutes.
tips: Total cook time: 1-3 hours depending on recipe
Soap may climb sides of cooker; push down
Done when soap is translucent and doesn't zap tongue
warnings: Soap can volcano if heat is too high
Don't taste-test until soap looks done

steps.title: Test for completion
steps.description: Soap is done when a small amount touched to tongue doesn't zap (no tingle). Soap should be translucent and vaseline-like in texture.
tips: Zap test: touch tiny amount to tongue tip
No zap = saponification complete
If it zaps, cook longer and retest

steps.title: Add extras after cook
steps.description: Remove from heat. Stir in essential oils, colourants, and additives quickly while soap is still workable.
tips: Work quickly; soap thickens as it cools
Add 1-2 tbsp water if too thick
Fragrance may flash off if soap is too hot

steps.title: Mould and unmould
steps.description: Glop soap into mould, pressing firmly to eliminate air pockets. Tap mould to settle. Unmould after 24 hours; no cutting needed for individual cavities.
tips: Press firmly to avoid air pockets
Wet hands help with pressing
Texture will be rustic, not smooth

steps.title: Cure (optional but recommended)
steps.description: While technically usable immediately, curing for 2-4 weeks improves bar hardness and mildness.
tips: Shorter cure needed than cold process
2-4 weeks produces much nicer bar
Water still needs to evaporate for hardness

advantages: Usable much sooner than cold process
Can salvage failed cold process batches
Superfat oils added after cook stay unsaponified

references.note: Saponification chemistry; hot process accelerates completion
